item.title: Quantic Dream developing multiplayer title; Star Wars: Eclipse development ongoing
item.content:encoded:
"Together, we believe we can create something truly unique."

Quantic Dream is developing a “competitive multiplayer experience,” studio head David Cage said in a message on the company’s official website. It is one of multiple games in the works, including the 2021-announced Star Wars: Eclipse, which Cage confirmed is ongoing.

“This new title may surprise our fans as it is very different from what we have done so far,” Cage said. “But taking risks, challenging ourselves, exploring new ways of playing and telling stories, and attempting what seems impossible, has always been part of our DNA.”

Here is the full message from Cage:

For over 28 years, Quantic Dream has been pushing the boundaries of interactive storytelling. With award-winning titles like Heavy Rain, Beyond: Two Souls, and Detroit: Become Human, more than 25 million players worldwide have shared the journeys of Ethan Mars, Jodie Holmes, Kara, Markus, and Connor, with us.

Since 2018, we have entered a new phase of growth and innovation. We doubled the size of the team, bringing together talents from all over the world united by the same passion for creativity. We opened a new studio in Montreal, moved into new headquarters in Paris, built the next generation of our proprietary technology, and became our own publisher.

After years as a single-project studio, we also decided to take a new step. Multiple teams are fully dedicated to crafting the next generation of great games, including something very different, a competitive multiplayer experience, born from the same spirit of curiosity and creativity that has always defined us.

This new title may surprise our fans as it is very different from what we have done so far. But taking risks, challenging ourselves, exploring new ways of playing and telling stories, and attempting what seems impossible, has always been part of our DNA.

We also know how demanding it is to create something new. Earning the trust of players, standing out in such a competitive space, and introducing fresh concepts is incredibly challenging. And since we have no legacy in this genre, we know we have everything to prove—which is why your support and feedback will be essential. Together, we believe we can create something truly unique.

Of course, development of Star Wars: Eclipse continues, and we are eager to share more with you in the future.

I want to take this opportunity to thank all our fans around the world for playing our games year after year, for their kind words whenever we meet, for their patience and encouragement.

This is the beginning of a new chapter for Quantic Dream. Thank you for being with us on this journey, we can’t wait to share what comes next.

—David Cage

item.title: Tomonobu Itagaki dies at age 58
item.content:encoded:
Tomonobu Itagaki, the former Tecmo director who created the Dead or Alive series, as well as the modern NINJA GAIDEN series in 2004, has passed away. He was 58 years old.

The following message was posted today on Itagaki’s Facebook page:

My Last Words

The light of my life is finally about to fade.

The fact that this message has been posted means that the time has come at last. I am no longer in this world.

(This final message was entrusted to someone dear to me.)

My life was a series of battles. I kept on winning.

I also caused a lot of trouble.

I take pride in having fought through to the end according to my own convictions.

I have no regrets.

However, I am filled with sorrow that I was unable to deliver a new work to my fans. I’m sorry.

That’s how it is.

So it goes.

—Tomonobu Itagaki

Opening week sales for Battlefield 6 and Little Nightmares III.

Famitsu has published its estimated physical game software data for Japan for week of October 6, 2025 to October 12, 2025.

Battlefield 6 for PlayStation 5 was the highest selling single SKU new release of the week, opening at 23,292 retail sales.

Little Nightmares III launched at 17,806 units on Switch, 7,040 units on PlayStation 5, and 6,924 units on Switch 2 for an opening week total of 31,770 retail copies sold.

On the hardware side, Switch 2 sold 46,842 units, the Switch family sold 23,149 units, the PlayStation 5 family sold 14,800 units, the Xbox Series family sold 237 units, and the PlayStation 4 family sold 17 units.
